prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3, field 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarimetric observations in B3 of the 6 PACO faint sample sources with S(20 GHz>200 mJy in the "field 1" (ecliptic latitude<-85deg).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This science goal includes the polarimetric observations in B3 of the 6 PACO faint sample sources with S(20 GHz>200 mJy in the "field 1" (ecliptic latitude<-85deg). According to the average spectral behaviour of the PACO faint sources between 20 and 100 GHz (estimated combining ATCA and Planck data) we expect a minimum flux density of 60 mJy at 100 GHz. Assuming a minimum fractional polarization of 1% at 100 (comparable to the minima measured by Trippe et al. 2012) we expect polarized flux densities >0.6mJy. A sensitivity limit of 0.1mJy should give >6 snr detections for all the sources.
The sources have been selected as being point-like in the AT20G survey which means that they fall within the survey synthesized beam of about 10 arcsec at 20 GHz. At the highest frequencies the emission should be dominated by the most compact regions, hence we expect that our target sizes fall well within one third of the ALMA band 3 primary beam, or are point like also for the ALMA resolution.
Due to the limit of 10deg distance among the targets in the same Science Goal (SG), we split the targets into 7 SGs for each frequency corresponding to 10deg radius circles (of which one is centered in the ecliptic pole and the others surround it). Given the continuum spectral setup allowed for polarimetric observations in Cycle 2 at 100 GHz, the requested sensitivity could be reached in <1min on source. The observations of all the targets, the calibration, and the overhead sum up to about 5hr, that is well below the indication of the OT of 21 hr. The latter arises from the need of 3hr of coverage to get a proper leakage calibration, considering independent leakage calibrations for each SG. If our project is not considered extremely time-consuming for this reason we can rely on the standard system-defined calibration.
However, we consider that, given the closeness of the 7 SG source positions, they can share the leakage calibration, and the whole project can be observed in 6hr (the minimum requested for two independent polarisation calibrations). For example, this could be achieved separating the SGs into two blocks (namely SGs 1-3 and 4-7). The SGs in each block have to be observed sequentially (i.e. one after the other) and the leakage calibrator can be observed only at the beginning of each science goal and after 3hr from the beginning of the first SG observation. We think that this will allow us enough calibration for our purposes, reducing the time requested for our project to about 6 hr.

According to the average spectral behaviour of the PACO faint sources between 20 and 100 GHz (estimated combining ATCA and Planck data) we expect a minimum flux density of 60 mJy at 100 GHz. The sources have been selected as being point-like in the AT20G survey which means that they fall within the survey synthesized beam of about 10 arcsec at 20 GHz. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to measure the polarized flux density in band 3 of a complete sample of 53 radio sources selected in the Australia Telescope 20 GHz (AT20G) survey as those having S(20 GHz)>200 mJy in the region with ecliptic latitude <-75dec. The sample is part of the Planck ATCA Coeval Observation sample that was used to estimate the radio-source contamination to the total intensity CMB power spectrum detected by the Planck satellite and to validate the Planck source catalogue (Bonavera et al. 2012). Polarimetric observations of the sample have already been carried out with the ATCA in the framework of the AT20G and PACO observations, up to 20GHz and with shallower sensitivity (Massardi et al. 2008, 2013). Extending the characterization of the polarisation properties of radio sources to higher frequencies and sensitivity, as possible only with ALMA for Southern hemisphere objects, provides information about the physics and geometry of the synchrotron emission regions, and on matter distributions of the surrounding or outflowing matter. Finally, with the ALMA data we will be able to investigate the radio-source contamination to the CMB polarization power spectrum in the mm bands.
